Decentralized and Model-Free Federated Learning: Consensus-Based Distillation in Function Space

Akihito Taya,  Takayuki Nishio,  Masahiro Morikura,  and Koji Yamamoto Akihito Taya is with the College of Science and Engineering, Department of Integrated Information Technology, Aoyama Gakuin University, Sagamihara 252-5258, Japan (e-mail: taya@it.aoyama.ac.jp)Takayuki Nishio is with the School of Engineering, Tokyo Tech., Japan (e-mail: nishio@ict.e.titech.ac.jp)Masahiro Morikura and Koji Yamamoto are with the Graduate School of Informatics, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-8501, Japan (e-mail: kyamamot@i.kyoto-u.ac.jpManuscript received April 19, 2005; revised August 26, 2015.
Abstract

This paper proposes a fully decentralized federated learning (FL) scheme for Internet of Everything (IoE) devices that are connected via multi-hop networks. Because FL algorithms hardly converge the parameters of machine learning (ML) models, this paper focuses on the convergence of ML models in function spaces. Considering that the representative loss functions of ML tasks e.g., mean squared error (MSE) and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, are convex functionals, algorithms that directly update functions in function spaces could converge to the optimal solution. The key concept of this paper is to tailor a consensus-based optimization algorithm to work in the function space and achieve the global optimum in a distributed manner. This paper first analyzes the convergence of the proposed algorithm in a function space, which is referred to as a meta-algorithm, and shows that the spectral graph theory can be applied to the function space in a manner similar to that of numerical vectors. Then, consensus-based multi-hop federated distillation (CMFD) is developed for a neural network (NN) to implement the meta-algorithm. CMFD leverages knowledge distillation to realize function aggregation among adjacent devices without parameter averaging. An advantage of CMFD is that it works even with different NN models among the distributed learners. Although CMFD does not perfectly reflect the behavior of the meta-algorithm, the discussion of the meta-algorithm’s convergence property promotes an intuitive understanding of CMFD, and simulation evaluations show that NN models converge using CMFD for several tasks. The simulation results also show that CMFD achieves higher accuracy than parameter aggregation for weakly connected networks, and CMFD is more stable than parameter aggregation methods.

Index Terms:
machine learning, federated learning, knowledge distillation, consensus-based distributed optimization, multi-hop network, distributed learning, IoE

I Introduction

The Internet of Everything (IoE) is a paradigm in which commonly used devices (e.g., machines, smartphones, cars, houses, and also humans) are connected and interact with each other. These devices have various sensors to perceive the real world and share information. Such data accelerate data-driven analysis and machine learning (ML), particularly deep learning (DL). IoE devices are able to provide ML agents with images, sound, physiological signals, and various data to train ML models for semantic analysis, prediction, as well as many other tasks. However, several challenges are encountered when utilizing the sensor data for ML. Protecting privacy is one of the most important problems. For example, it is preferable not to upload users’ photos, conversations, and behavioral data stored in IoE devices to data centers.

Federated learning (FL) has been proposed to avoid uploading data for preserving user privacy [1, 2]. Instead of collecting data to a server, FL updates neural network (NN) models at local devices (e.g., smartphones) using their private data and uploads the updated NN-parameters (i.e., weights and biases of each layer) to the server. Then, the server gathers and aggregates the uploaded parameters and broadcasts the up-to-date parameters to the local devices. The left side of Fig. 1 shows the parameter-aggregation scheme. This algorithm realizes distributed learning without exposing the user data to the centric learner. Since the FL was first introduced in [1], many types of FL have been developed to solve problems that appear in practical situations [2].

Typical FL schemes require servers to manage client devices and aggregate parameters, whereas IoE devices are expected to operate without a server because they are sometimes connected via multi-hop networks, through which devices can directly communicate only with adjacent ones. This constraint makes it difficult to adopt FL, which requires a central server [3]. Therefore, multi-hop FL algorithms have been developed [4, 3, 5, 6, 7], through which devices share information only with adjacent devices. Multi-hop FL can solve some problems of centralized FL. First, multi-hop FL does not suffer from communication bottlenecks in the servers. Therefore, the number of FL-participating devices is easily increased, and a large amount of training data can be utilized for learning. Second, considering that some information is sent to other devices even if it does not include private data, users often feel concerns when sending information to unknown devices. Therefore, the study of multi-hop FL should be motivated to realize higher scalability and security than a centralized one.

Although multi-hop FL algorithms were studied in [4, 3, 5, 6, 7], the following challenges remain.

Model constraint

Existing works assume that all the devices have the same NN model architecture (e.g., the number of layers, hidden nodes, and how they are connected). However, considering that IoE devices have different computational resources, it is better to use different NN models depending on their computational capacities. Besides, if some IoE device vendors collaborate in a single FL system, they may prefer to keep their NN models secret. Therefore, the constraint should preferably be eased and allow the devices to decide their NN models by themselves depending on their own conditions.

Convergence analysis under non-IID situations

The convergence of multi-hop FL is not guaranteed because multi-hop FL tasks are formulated as decentralized non-convex optimization problems. If centralized FL algorithms are adopted, all devices can synchronize their parameters at the end of each iteration because there is a parameter server that manages and broadcasts a global model. Conversely, it is not generally guaranteed when using decentralized algorithms in which all devices obtain the same model because there is no opportunity for synchronizing all models. In addition, multi-hop FL more severely suffers from non-independent and identically distributed (IID) problems than centralized FL. It is usual in FL that data distributions vary across devices because of users’ interests and conditions [2]. Such situations, termed non-IID ness, which has been widely studied [18, 19, 20], drastically degrades FL performance. In contrast to centralized FL, multi-hop FL is further affected by non-IID ness because NN models are shared only among adjacent devices.

To solve these problems, we first propose a decentralized FL algorithm that optimizes the prediction functions in a function space. The proposed algorithm is referred to as a meta-algorithm in this paper because it can be applied to NNs and other gradient-descent-based ML algorithms, such as the gradient boosting decision tree (GBDT). The meta-algorithm iteratively trains the local prediction functions using functional gradients and aggregates them with adjacent devices by applying consensus-based distributed optimization (CDO) to guarantee convergence even in multi-hop networks. Because typical ML tasks are convex functional optimization problems, the meta-algorithm, which works in a function space and does not handle parameters, can solve them, and convergence is achieved by gradient-descent-based methods using functional gradients.

To improve the practicality, we adopt a gradient descent scheme, which is widely spread and easily implementable. In the context of IoE, where different manufacturers develop diverse devices, some devices do not have enough computational resources to implement complicated algorithms, and some manufacturers prefer to reduce the development costs.

The convergence of the meta-algorithm is mathematically analyzed in a function space because the convergence in a function space is practically sufficient, whereas the convergence in a parameter space is difficult to achieve. To analyze how local prediction functions draw close in a function space when using the meta-algorithm, we utilize spectral graph theory to prove convergence. The analysis is divided into two parts: the convergence among the devices provided in Theorem 1 and the convergence to the global optimum provided in Theorem 2. Through the analysis, we do not use the information of the representation of ML models considering the situations where some types of models are adopted by different devices and they do not share their information. We develop an analysis scheme that utilizes only function distances because the distance can be calculated without specifying the representation.

By focusing on the behavior of gradient descent in a function space, we successfully proved the convergence of the meta-algorithm and provided an upper bound under non-IID situations. We also revealed the effects of network connectivity on the convergence rate in the function space. To do so, we proved Lemma 1, which is used in the proof of Theorem 1, to analyze the convergence of functions. Lemma 1 states that the induced norm of matrices corresponding in real-vector and stacked function spaces are the same. This fact enables us to analyze convergence in function spaces in a similar manner as that in numerical vector spaces. It is also notable that the meta-algorithm operates in a decentralized manner and is scalable to the number of devices owing to the CDO scheme.

A consensus-based multi-hop federated distillation (CMFD) is developed as a NN version of the meta-algorithm because it cannot be implemented directly. Fig. 1 shows an overview of our CMFD, and the characteristics of CMFD are compared with other FL algorithms in Table I. CMFD addresses one of the impracticalities of the meta-algorithm: the difficulty of aggregating prediction functions in a function space. Because boosting algorithms, for example, GBDT, are functional gradient methods as explained in [21], the meta-algorithm is easily applied to boosting algorithms by considering weak learners as functional gradients. However, stochastic gradient descent (SGD)-based algorithms for NN are parametric, and an implementation scheme must be developed. The calculation of aggregated prediction functions among adjacent devices is a technical problem because it is difficult to determine the parameters 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} that satisfy f​(𝒙;𝒘)=∑ifi​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙𝒘subscript𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙f(\bm{x};\bm{w})=\sum_{i}f_{i}(\bm{x}) for given prediction functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}. We show a toy model how CMFD tackles function aggregation using distillation in Appendix A.

Function aggregation is not a challenge when adopting ensemble ML or kernel machines [22], because the aggregated functions can be calculated as the linear sum of the weak learners or kernel functions.

We utilize distillation schemes [23] to adjust the parameters of NN s to achieve aggregation in function spaces. In the CMFD, the outputs of local functions of adjacent devices are aggregated, and the devices train their local functions regarding the aggregated outputs as labels. The local functions approach the aggregated function using this scheme. Although distillation requires the same inputs to be shared, public open data can be utilized to avoid sharing private data [10]. In addition, distillation allows the devices to adopt different NN models because the devices do not directly share their parameters. Thus, the devices can independently update the parameters of their NN models without considering the parameters of other devices. This scheme relaxes the constraints of FL and is suitable for IoE systems, where the devices have different computational resources. Distillation methods are applied in centralized FL [24, 25, 8, 9, 10, 12, 11] because of communication efficiency. However, to the best of our knowledge, distillation-based FL in multi-hop networks has not been studied.

The contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    To decentralize the ML models’ training for IoE systems, we propose an algorithm, termed a meta-algorithm, that optimizes ML models in a function space. The meta-algorithm adopts a CDO scheme to solve convex functional optimization problems under the conditions in which IoE devices communicate with their adjacent devices and update prediction functions without a coordinator.

  2. 2.

    We analyzed the convergence of the proposed meta-algorithm in a function space without the knowledge of the other devices’ ML representations. Spectral graph theory is used to prove convergence with non-IID data in a decentralized manner. We also revealed how network connectivity affects the convergence rate by extending the spectral graph theory to function spaces.

  3. 3.

    We develop a CMFD for NNs as an implementation of the meta-algorithm. Even though a distributed learning of NNs is a non-convex parameter optimization problem, our algorithm leverages a distillation scheme to update parameters so that prediction functions trace the trajectory of solving convex function optimization.

  4. 4.

    CMFD works in a fully distributed manner over multi-hop networks with non-IID data. Owing to distillation, CMFD can be adopted even when the NN architectures among the devices differ, which is suitable for IoE devices with various computational resources. To the best of our knowledge, conventional FL algorithms cannot have all these features simultaneously.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Related works are discussed in Section II. The problem definition is described in Section III. The proposed algorithm is explained in Section IV and is evaluated in Section V. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section VI.

II Related works

Decentralized learning algorithms in multi-hop networks

Multi-hop FL for IoE devices was introduced in [4, 3, 5, 7]. Savazzi et al. [3] developed a multi-hop FL algorithm that shares both model updates and gradients to improve convergence. Lalitha et al. [4] proposed a Bayesian approach to estimate the global model and tackle non-IID problems by updating and aggregating beliefs with neighbors. However, the evaluations were limited to a few nodes, and it is still uncertain whether the algorithm converges with many devices. Lian et al. [5] proposed parallel SGD in multi-hop topologies and showed that decentralized parallel SGD (D-PSGD) accelerates learning when the channel capacity of the centralized server is a bottleneck because of narrow bandwidths. Sato et al. [7] extended D-PSGD to apply it to wireless networks by considering the channel capacity of each link. These algorithms are operated and analyzed in a parameter space, fundamentally requiring identical NN model architectures among all devices, which decreases the flexibility of FL systems. In contrast to these algorithms, we utilize distillation to aggregate NN models to realize model-free FL.

Distillation

While a typical FL must send all the parameters of the NN, distillation-based FL sends only the output of the prediction function, which usually has smaller dimensions than the NN parameters. Therefore, federated distillation (FD) is proposed to realize communication-efficient algorithms [8, 9, 10, 12, 11]. Mix2FLD proposed in [8] uses FL for downlink and FD for uplink to address the uplink-downlink capacity asymmetry. A hybrid FD was proposed in [9] to compensate for the performance gap between FL and FD by using covariate information among the devices. In [10], unlabeled open data are leveraged to realize semi-supervised FD. Jeong et al. [11] proposed federated augmentation (FAug) by extending FD. FAug leverages a generative adversarial network (GAN) to generate IID datasets while preserving privacy. FAug is extended to MultFAug in [15] to be used in multi-hop networks. MultFAug sends NN model information via multi-hop networks, but model aggregation is centralized. A centralized algorithm cannot be scaled to the number of devices because bottleneck problems arise when aggregating NN models.

In contrast to [8, 9, 10, 12, 11], which use central units, [16, 17] applied distillation to decentralized learning. These works show that speed and cost-efficiency are advantages of distillation-based decentralized learning. However, the evaluations in [16, 17] assume fully connected topologies and IID training data, which are not found in IoE systems. In addition, if each device must share data with all the other devices, the amount of transferred data increases with the number of devices, consequently, the fully connected algorithm cannot be applied to systems with a large number of devices. Our algorithm can be applied to devices connected via multi-hop networks, which is useful for IoE systems.

Cronus [12], FedMD [13], and FedDF [14] leveraged distillation to realize heterogeneous FL where different NN models can be used, whereas the above-mentioned studies utilized distillation to reduce communication costs and improve performance. Unlike these algorithms that require a central server, the proposed algorithm realizes decentralized FL with heterogeneous models.

Distributed optimization

Distributed optimization problems have been discussed for wireless sensor networks (WSN), and many associated algorithms have been developed. One of these algorithms is called CDO, which can solve convex optimization problems typically designed as follows:

minimizeθ∈ℝn​∑iFi​(θ),subscriptminimize𝜃superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃\displaystyle\operatorname*{minimize}_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\sum_{i}F_{i}(\theta), (1)

where the function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is only known to agent i𝑖i, and each agent exchanges information with only one-hop neighbors [26, 27, 28]. With CDO, agents individually update parameters θ𝜃\theta by gradient descent and then share the parameters with their neighbors. These steps are iterated until the parameters converge to the optimal solution. If optimization problems are convex, convergence to the global optimum is proved in [26, 27, 28]. CDO is also applied to multi-hop ML by regarding Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} in (1) as a loss function with local private data and θ𝜃\theta as the NN parameters [4, 3, 7]. Alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) is also applied to decentralized ML. Elgabli et al. proposed a group ADMM (GADMM) to solve convex ML tasks in [29]. Niwa et al. proposed primal-dual method of multipliers (PDMM) [6], which shows a strong convergence even in weakly connected networks, for FL.

However, training NN tasks are non-convex optimization problems, and, therefore, convergence is not guaranteed. When multiple devices approach the different local optima by gradient descent, the direction calculated by parameter aggregation can differ from those of the gradient descent updates, and performance is degraded. To overcome this problem, our concept is to perform CDO in a function space that optimizes not parameters but prediction functions themselves by regarding a supervised ML task as a functional optimization; that is, θ𝜃\theta and Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} in (1) become the prediction function f𝑓f and loss functional 𝖫isubscript𝖫𝑖\mathsf{L}_{i} depending on local data, respectively, as follows:

minimizef∈ℱ​∑i𝖫i​(f),subscriptminimize𝑓ℱsubscript𝑖subscript𝖫𝑖𝑓\displaystyle\operatorname*{minimize}_{f\in\mathcal{F}}\sum_{i}\mathsf{L}_{i}(f), (2)

where ℱℱ\mathcal{F} denotes the function space. It is expected that CDO in a function space can decentralize the multi-hop FL solution because the commonly used ML criteria, mean squared error (MSE) and Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, are convex functionals regarding a prediction function as an argument [30], even though prediction models are non-linear functions with respect to their parameters. Our algorithm can learn non-IID data because CDO is designed to work even when the 𝖫isubscript𝖫𝑖\mathsf{L}_{i} among devices differs.

CDO-based algorithms in function spaces were proposed in [22, 31, 32, 33]. These algorithms assume reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), which is a function space in which any function can be represented by a linear combination of coefficients and kernels. In RKHS, aggregated functions are calculated by adding coefficients and sharing kernels. Therefore, the convergence of functions can be analyzed in real-vector spaces. In contrast, we analyze convergence in L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} space without using kernels; therefore, the analysis is more versatile. Additionally, we prove the convergence with non-IID datasets, which is not considered in [22, 31, 32, 33]. We introduce Radon-Nikodym derivative to represent skewness among local spaces depending on skewed data distributions to analyze the convergence in non-IID situations. The results indicate how this skewness affects convergence in non-IID situations.

III Problem statement

We consider that IoE devices with sensors are connected via a multi-hop network, and each device i𝑖i can only communicate with its adjacent devices 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i} in each step. Device i𝑖i manages its prediction model fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} and updates fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} with its local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} using a ML scheme. The local dataset should not be shared because it includes private information. Therefore, instead of sharing dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, the devices share some information representing fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} with their adjacent devices 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}. By using the received information, the devices train their prediction model fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} to be optimal even if the local datasets are non-IID. The mathematical problem is formulated as follows:

Let 𝒳⊆ℝN𝒳superscriptℝ𝑁\mathcal{X}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{N} and 𝒴⊆ℝM𝒴superscriptℝ𝑀\mathcal{Y}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{M} be an input space (or feature space) and an output space, respectively. We denote by f:𝒳→𝒴:𝑓→𝒳𝒴f:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y} as a prediction function, and f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star} as the ground truth function. Let l​(𝒚,𝒚′):𝒴×𝒴→ℝ:𝑙𝒚superscript𝒚′→𝒴𝒴ℝl(\bm{y},\bm{y}^{\prime}):\mathcal{Y}\times\mathcal{Y}\to\mathbb{R} be the cost function of each element 𝒚,𝒚′∈𝒴𝒚superscript𝒚′𝒴\bm{y},\bm{y}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}. When the MSE criterion is used, l​(𝒚,𝒚′)𝑙𝒚superscript𝒚′l(\bm{y},\bm{y}^{\prime}) is defined as l​(𝒚,𝒚′)≔∥𝒚−𝒚′∥2≔𝑙𝒚superscript𝒚′superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒚superscript𝒚′2l(\bm{y},\bm{y}^{\prime})\coloneqq\left\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert^{2}, and when the KL divergence is used, it is defined as l​(𝒚,𝒚′)≔∑m=1Mym​log⁡ymym′≔𝑙𝒚superscript𝒚′superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑦𝑚subscript𝑦𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑦′𝑚l(\bm{y},\bm{y}^{\prime})\coloneqq\sum_{m=1}^{M}y_{m}\log\frac{y_{m}}{y^{\prime}_{m}}, where ymsubscript𝑦𝑚y_{m} denotes the m𝑚mth element of vector 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}. Here, a global loss functional 𝖫μ​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f) and local loss functional 𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f) for each user i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U} are defined as follows:

𝖫μ​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\displaystyle\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f) ≔∫𝒳l​(f​(𝒙),f⋆​(𝒙))​dμ,≔absentsubscript𝒳𝑙𝑓𝒙superscript𝑓⋆𝒙differential-d𝜇\displaystyle\coloneqq\int_{\mathcal{X}}l\left(f(\bm{x}),f^{\star}(\bm{x})\right)\mathrm{d}\mu, (3)
𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\displaystyle\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f) ≔∫𝒳l​(f​(𝒙),f⋆​(𝒙))​dμi,≔absentsubscript𝒳𝑙𝑓𝒙superscript𝑓⋆𝒙differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑖\displaystyle\coloneqq\int_{\mathcal{X}}l\left(f(\bm{x}),f^{\star}(\bm{x})\right)\mathrm{d}\mu_{i}, (4)

where μ𝜇\mu and μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} represent a global and local probability measure on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, respectively, and 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} represents a set of users. We use an integral form of risk minimization [34] because the meta-algorithm is designed to work in a function space that does not depend on a dataset. We denote by Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} the L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} space with respect to μ𝜇\mu and by ⟨⋅,⋅⟩Lμ2subscript⋅⋅subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{L^{2}_{\mu}} an inner product and norm are defined as ⟨f,g⟩Lμ2≔∫𝒳⟨f​(𝒙),g​(𝒙)⟩𝒴​dμ≔subscript𝑓𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇subscript𝒳subscript𝑓𝒙𝑔𝒙𝒴differential-d𝜇\langle f,g\rangle_{L^{2}_{\mu}}\coloneqq\int_{\mathcal{X}}\langle f(\bm{x}),g(\bm{x})\rangle_{\mathcal{Y}}\,\mathrm{d}\mu and ∥f∥Lμ2≔⟨f,f⟩Lμ2≔subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇subscript𝑓𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇\left\lVert f\right\rVert_{L^{2}_{\mu}}\coloneqq\sqrt{\langle f,f\rangle_{L^{2}_{\mu}}}, respectively, where ⟨⋅,⋅⟩𝒴subscript⋅⋅𝒴\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{\mathcal{Y}} represents the inner product in vector space 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}.

This paper focuses on convex loss functionals in the function space Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} because the commonly used criteria (e.g., MSE and KL divergence [30]) are convex.

Assumption 1

𝖫μ​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f) and 𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f) satisfy the following inequalities for all f1subscript𝑓1f_{1}, f2subscript𝑓2f_{2}, and t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in\left[0,1\right]:

𝖫μ​(t​f1+(1−t)​f2)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑡subscript𝑓11𝑡subscript𝑓2\displaystyle\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(tf_{1}+(1-t)f_{2}) ≤t​𝖫μ​(f1)+(1−t)​𝖫μ​(f2),absent𝑡subscript𝖫𝜇subscript𝑓11𝑡subscript𝖫𝜇subscript𝑓2\displaystyle\leq t\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f_{1})+(1-t)\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f_{2}), (5)
𝖫μi​(t​f1+(1−t)​f2)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑡subscript𝑓11𝑡subscript𝑓2\displaystyle\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(tf_{1}+(1-t)f_{2}) ≤t​𝖫μi​(f1)+(1−t)​𝖫μi​(f2).absent𝑡subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑓11𝑡subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑓2\displaystyle\leq t\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f_{1})+(1-t)\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f_{2}). (6)

To discuss the convergence of the gradient descent algorithm, both the global and local loss functionals are assumed to be Lipschitz continuous. In contrast to [5], which assumes Lipschitz gradient continuity in a parameter space, we assume Lipschitz continuity in a function space.

Assumption 2

𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f) satisfies the Lipschitz condition for all f1subscript𝑓1f_{1} and f2subscript𝑓2f_{2}:

|𝖫μi​(f1)−𝖫μi​(f2)|≤Ki​∥f1−f2∥𝖫μi,subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑓1subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑓2subscript𝐾𝑖subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑓1subscript𝑓2subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖\displaystyle|\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f_{1})-\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f_{2})|\leq K_{i}\left\lVert f_{1}-f_{2}\right\rVert_{\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}}, (7)

where Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} denotes the Lipschitz constant of 𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f).

This condition is similar to the assumption of the gradient limit considered in [20] because the Lipschitz constant corresponds to the maximum of the gradients. Note that not all tasks satisfy this assumption; e.g., 𝖫μisubscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}} is defined as the squared L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} norm, and the trained functions are not limited to probability measures. However, gradient methods can practically be applied even when this assumption is not satisfied [35].

In the considered system, it is assumed that the ground truth function is common among users, but the probability measures μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} vary across users, that is, users have non-IID data. This setting is referred to as “feature distribution skew” and “label distribution skew” in [2]. Considering the meaning of the global probability measure, it is empirically represented as μ=1n​∑i∈𝒰μi𝜇1𝑛subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝜇𝑖\mu=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\mu_{i}, where n𝑛n represents a number of users. Using this, global loss functional 𝖫μ​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f) can be written as 𝖫μ​(f)=1n​∑i∈𝒰𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓1𝑛subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f). It is also notable that μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} is absolutely continuous with respect to μ𝜇\mu (μi≪μmuch-less-thansubscript𝜇𝑖𝜇\mu_{i}\ll\mu) and there exists Radon-Nikodym derivative νi=d​μid​μsubscript𝜈𝑖dsubscript𝜇𝑖d𝜇\nu_{i}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\mu_{i}}{\mathrm{d}\mu} for all i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U}. We denote by Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} the supremum of νi​(𝒙)subscript𝜈𝑖𝒙\nu_{i}(\bm{x}), that is, Si≔supx∈𝒳νi​(𝒙)≔subscript𝑆𝑖subscriptsupremum𝑥𝒳subscript𝜈𝑖𝒙S_{i}\coloneqq\sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\nu_{i}(\bm{x}). This value is regarded as a metric of non-IID ness because it takes the minimum value of 111 when μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} and μ𝜇\mu are the same.

In the ML context, because the true loss functional 𝖫μ​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f) cannot be obtained, the following approximation, called empirical risk, is used:

𝖫μ​(f)subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\displaystyle\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f) ≈1|𝒟|​∑(𝒙,𝒚)∈𝒟l​(f​(𝒙),𝒚)absent1𝒟subscript𝒙𝒚𝒟𝑙𝑓𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\approx\frac{1}{|{\mathcal{D}}|}\sum_{(\bm{x},\bm{y})\in\mathcal{D}}l\left(f(\bm{x}),\bm{y}\right)
=1n​∑i∈𝒰1|𝒟i|​∑(𝒙,𝒚)∈𝒟il​(f​(𝒙),𝒚),absent1𝑛subscript𝑖𝒰1subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝒙𝒚subscript𝒟𝑖𝑙𝑓𝒙𝒚\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\frac{1}{|{\mathcal{D}_{i}}|}\sum_{(\bm{x},\bm{y})\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}l\left(f(\bm{x}),\bm{y}\right), (8)

where 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, and |⋅||{\cdot}| respectively denote a labeled dataset of each device, the union of all the data sets 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, and the cardinality of a set. Here, we assume |𝒟i|=1n​|𝒟|subscript𝒟𝑖1𝑛𝒟|{\mathcal{D}_{i}}|=\frac{1}{n}|{\mathcal{D}}| for all i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U} for simplicity, but it is easily extended to general cases. When f𝑓f is represented by a NN model with parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, the optimization problem is defined in a parameter space instead of the function space as follows:

minimize𝒘∈ℝnw𝖫μ​(f​(⋅;𝒘)),subscriptminimize𝒘superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑤subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓⋅𝒘\displaystyle\operatorname*{minimize}_{\bm{w}\in{\mathbb{R}^{n_{w}}}}\quad\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f(\cdot;\bm{w})), (9)

where nwsubscript𝑛𝑤n_{w} denotes the number of parameters. To realize FL in multi-hop networks, this optimization problem should be solved under the constraints that each device i𝑖i shares information only with its adjacent devices denoted by 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}.

CDO was applied in [3, 4] to solve (9) in a distributed manner. However, such algorithms do not work efficiently because the objective functions are not convex in a parameter space, and CDO cannot be generally applied to non-convex optimization problems. Thus, CDO in a parameter space can achieve only low performance in the ML context, especially when the local data is non-IID. In contrast to conventional works that optimize parameters w𝑤w, we develop an algorithm that optimizes f𝑓f directly. Considering that CDO achieves an optimal solution when the objective function is convex, the following optimization problem is expected to be solved,

minimizef∈Lμ2𝖫μ​(f).subscriptminimize𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇subscript𝖫𝜇𝑓\displaystyle\operatorname*{minimize}_{f\in L^{2}_{\mu}}\quad\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(f). (10)

The following section explains how to solve this optimization problem and prove the convergence of the proposed algorithm.

IV Consensus-based multi-hop federated learning

IV-A Meta-algorithm in a function space

First, we explain a meta-algorithm in a function space Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} to solve (10) and prove that the prediction functions of all devices converge to the optimal solution. Subsequently, distillation is introduced in Sec. IV-C to apply the proposed meta-algorithm to the NN models.

To solve (9), existing CDO-based FL schemes in a parameter space [3, 5, 4, 7] update local models using the following equations:

𝒘^it+1superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t+1} ←𝒘it−ηt​∇𝒘​∑(x,y)∈𝒟il​(f​(𝒙;𝒘it),𝒚),←absentsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript∇𝒘subscript𝑥𝑦subscript𝒟𝑖𝑙𝑓𝒙superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡𝒚\displaystyle\leftarrow\bm{w}_{i}^{t}-\eta_{t}\nabla_{\bm{w}}\sum_{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}l(f(\bm{x};\bm{w}_{i}^{t}),\bm{y}), (11)
𝒘it+1superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1} ←𝒘^it+1−ε​∑j∈𝒩i(𝒘^it+1−𝒘^jt+1),←absentsuperscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1𝜀subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑗𝑡1\displaystyle\leftarrow\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t+1}-\varepsilon\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\left(\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t+1}-\hat{\bm{w}}_{j}^{t+1}\right), (12)

where 𝒘itsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}^{t}, 𝒘^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}, and ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} respectively represent the parameters of device i𝑖i at epoch t𝑡t, the temporal parameters, and the learning rate. We assume that ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} monotonically decreases and, therefore, ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} satisfies ηt≤η1subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜂1\eta_{t}\leq\eta_{1}. The coefficient ε𝜀\varepsilon of the second term of (12) is referred to as the sharing rate, which adjusts the convergence among devices. To operate (11) and (12), 𝒘^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t} should be shared among adjacent devices, and thus wide communication bandwidths are required when a NN model has many layers. In addition, the CDO is not guaranteed to reach the optimal solution for non-convex optimizations.

To tackle these problems, we replace parameter optimization by function optimization as follows:

git+1superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle g_{i}^{t+1} ←fit−ηt​dit​νi,←absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡subscript𝜈𝑖\displaystyle\leftarrow f_{i}^{t}-\eta_{t}d_{i}^{t}\nu_{i}, (13)
fit+1superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle f_{i}^{t+1} =git+1−ε​ni​(git+1−1ni​∑j∈𝒩igjt+1),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡1𝜀subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡11subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑗𝑡1\displaystyle=g_{i}^{t+1}-\varepsilon n_{i}\left(g_{i}^{t+1}-\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}g_{j}^{t+1}\right), (14)

where nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} represents the number of neighbors of user i𝑖i, defined by ni≔|𝒩i|≔subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝒩𝑖n_{i}\coloneqq|{\mathcal{N}_{i}}|. Here, dit∈∂𝖫μi​(fit)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡d_{i}^{t}\in\partial\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f_{i}^{t}) represents a Fréchet subgradient of the local loss functional 𝖫μi​(f)subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖𝑓\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f), which satisfies the following inequality [36]:

∀h∈Lμi2,⟨dit,h−fit⟩Lμi2≤𝖫μi​(h)−𝖫μi​(fit).formulae-sequencefor-allℎsubscriptsuperscript𝐿2subscript𝜇𝑖subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐿2subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖ℎsubscript𝖫subscript𝜇𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\forall h\in L^{2}_{\mu_{i}},\langle d_{i}^{t},h-f_{i}^{t}\rangle_{L^{2}_{\mu_{i}}}\leq\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(h)-\mathsf{L}_{\mu_{i}}(f_{i}^{t}). (15)

In (13), νi=d​μid​μsubscript𝜈𝑖dsubscript𝜇𝑖d𝜇\nu_{i}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\mu_{i}}{\mathrm{d}\mu} represents the skewness of subgradient ditsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡d_{i}^{t}, which is caused by mini-batch algorithms executed in Lμi2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2subscript𝜇𝑖L^{2}_{\mu_{i}} not in the global space Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu}. We assume that ε𝜀\varepsilon in (14) satisfies 0<ε≤12​Δ0𝜀12Δ0<\varepsilon\leq\frac{1}{2\Delta} where ΔΔ\Delta denotes the maximum degree of the network graph. This condition is required to guarantee convergence, as explained in Sec. IV-B.

Algorithm 1 shows pseudocode that applies the above operation. In each epoch, the devices update their local prediction functions fitsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡f_{i}^{t} by (13) (steps 4–5). After updating them, the devices share temporal functions git+1superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡1g_{i}^{t+1} with the adjacent devices 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i} (step 6). Then, the devices aggregate the received models and calculate the weighted average of the prediction functions (step 9). After iterating these steps, all the local prediction functions converge to the optimal solution f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star} of (10).

IV-B Convergence analysis of the meta-algorithm

The convergence analysis is divided into two parts. First, an upper bound is obtained of the distance between the local prediction functions fitsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡f_{i}^{t} and their average f¯tsubscript¯𝑓𝑡\bar{f}_{t}. Then, we discuss the limits of 𝖫μ​(f¯t)subscript𝖫𝜇subscript¯𝑓𝑡\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(\bar{f}_{t}) as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty.

In order to mathematically analyze the convergence of the meta-algorithm, we define a federated function 𝒇tsubscript𝒇𝑡\bm{f}_{t} as a tuple of prediction functions:

𝒇tsubscript𝒇𝑡\displaystyle\bm{f}_{t} ≔(f1t,…,fnt)T∈Φn≔(Lμ2)n,≔absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑓1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛𝑡TsubscriptΦ𝑛≔superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇𝑛\displaystyle\coloneqq\left(f_{1}^{t},\ldots,f_{n}^{t}\right)^{\mathrm{T}}\in\Phi_{n}\coloneqq\left(L^{2}_{\mu}\right)^{n}, (16)

where [⋅]Tsuperscriptdelimited-[]⋅T\left[\cdot\right]^{\mathrm{T}} denotes the transpose of [⋅]delimited-[]⋅\left[\cdot\right]. ΦnsubscriptΦ𝑛\Phi_{n} is the n𝑛n-ary Cartesian power of Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} with the inner product ⟨𝒂,𝒃⟩Φn≔∑i=1n⟨ai,bi⟩Lμ2≔subscript𝒂𝒃subscriptΦ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇\langle\bm{a},\bm{b}\rangle_{\Phi_{n}}\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{n}\langle a_{i},b_{i}\rangle_{L^{2}_{\mu}} and norm ∥𝒂∥Φn≔⟨𝒂,𝒂⟩Φn≔subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒂subscriptΦ𝑛subscript𝒂𝒂subscriptΦ𝑛\left\lVert\bm{a}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}\coloneqq\sqrt{\langle\bm{a},\bm{a}\rangle_{\Phi_{n}}} where aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} are the i𝑖ith elements of the federated functions 𝒂𝒂\bm{a} and 𝒃∈Φn𝒃subscriptΦ𝑛\bm{b}\in\Phi_{n}, respectively. The addition and scalar multiplication of federated functions are calculated in an element-wise manner. The product of the matrices and federated functions is defined similarly to that of matrices and numerical vectors, that is, the i𝑖ith element of A​𝒂∈Φn𝐴𝒂subscriptΦ𝑛A\bm{a}\in\Phi_{n} is defined as ∑j=1nAi​j​ajsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗subscript𝑎𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{n}A_{ij}a_{j}, where Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} denotes the (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) element of matrix A𝐴A.

The following lemma expresses the relation between the induced norm of real matrices and the federated functions.

Lemma 1

Let ∥A∥delimited-∥∥𝐴\left\lVert A\right\rVert be the induced norm of matrix A(∈ℝn×n)annotated𝐴absentsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑛A(\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}) corresponding to the 2-norm of real vectors, i.e.,

∥A∥≔max⁡{∥A​𝒗∥ℝn/∥𝒗∥ℝn|𝒗∈ℝn,𝒗≠𝟎}.≔delimited-∥∥𝐴subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐴𝒗superscriptℝ𝑛subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒗superscriptℝ𝑛𝒗superscriptℝ𝑛𝒗0\displaystyle\left\lVert A\right\rVert\coloneqq\max\left\{\left\lVert A\bm{v}\right\rVert_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}/\left\lVert\bm{v}\right\rVert_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\mathrel{}\middle|\mathrel{}\bm{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{n},\bm{v}\neq\bm{0}\right\}. (17)

Then, ∥A∥delimited-∥∥𝐴\left\lVert A\right\rVert is also the induced 2-norm of the federated functions, that is, ∥A∥delimited-∥∥𝐴\left\lVert A\right\rVert satisfies

∥A∥=max⁡{∥A​𝒂∥Φn/∥𝒂∥Φn|𝒂∈Φn,𝒂≠𝟎}.delimited-∥∥𝐴subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐴𝒂subscriptΦ𝑛subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒂subscriptΦ𝑛𝒂subscriptΦ𝑛𝒂0\displaystyle\left\lVert A\right\rVert=\max\left\{\left\lVert A\bm{a}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}/\left\lVert\bm{a}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}\mathrel{}\middle|\mathrel{}\bm{a}\in\Phi_{n},\bm{a}\neq\bm{0}\right\}. (18)
Proof:

See Appendix B. ∎

This lemma enables the convergence of Algorithm 1 in ΦnsubscriptΦ𝑛\Phi_{n} to be analyzed similarly to that in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}.

Using the federated functions, (13) and (14) can be rewritten as follows:

𝒈t+1subscript𝒈𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{g}_{t+1} ←𝒇t−ηt​𝒅t,←absentsubscript𝒇𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝒅𝑡\displaystyle\leftarrow\bm{f}_{t}-\eta_{t}\bm{d}_{t}, (19)
𝒇t+1subscript𝒇𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{f}_{t+1} ←𝒈t+1−ε​L​𝒈t+1=(I−ε​L)​𝒈t+1,←absentsubscript𝒈𝑡1𝜀𝐿subscript𝒈𝑡1𝐼𝜀𝐿subscript𝒈𝑡1\displaystyle\leftarrow\bm{g}_{t+1}-\varepsilon L\bm{g}_{t+1}=(I-\varepsilon L)\bm{g}_{t+1}, (20)

where 𝒈tsubscript𝒈𝑡\bm{g}_{t}, 𝒅tsubscript𝒅𝑡\bm{d}_{t}, I𝐼I, and L𝐿L denote federated functions the i𝑖ith elements of which are gitsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡g_{i}^{t} and dit​νisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡subscript𝜈𝑖d_{i}^{t}\nu_{i}, the identity matrix, and the Laplacian matrix of the network graph, respectively. The (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j)th element of L𝐿L is |𝒩i|subscript𝒩𝑖|{\mathcal{N}_{i}}| if i=j𝑖𝑗i=j, -1 if j∈𝒩i𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, or 0. Let λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} denote the second minimum eigenvalue of L𝐿L, which is also known as algebraic connectivity [37]. Generally, consensus algorithms converge faster if the value increases.

We denote by 𝒂¯¯𝒂\bar{\bm{a}} a mean federated function the elements of which are the mean of functions aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}, which is calculated as 𝒂¯≔1n​𝟏n×n​𝒂≔¯𝒂1𝑛subscript1𝑛𝑛𝒂\bar{\bm{a}}\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\bm{1}_{n\times n}\bm{a}, where 𝟏n×nsubscript1𝑛𝑛\bm{1}_{n\times n} represents an n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n matrix of ones. Using federated functions, the root-mean-square distance between the local prediction functions and their mean is expressed as follows:

Dt≔1n​∑i=1n∥fit−f¯t∥Lμ22=1n​∥𝒇t−𝒇¯t∥Φn,≔subscript𝐷𝑡1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡subscript¯𝑓𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇21𝑛subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒇𝑡subscript¯𝒇𝑡subscriptΦ𝑛\displaystyle D_{t}\coloneqq\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\lVert f_{i}^{t}-\bar{f}_{t}\right\rVert_{L^{2}_{\mu}}^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\lVert\bm{f}_{t}-\bar{\bm{f}}_{t}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}, (21)

where f¯tsubscript¯𝑓𝑡\bar{f}_{t} denotes the mean of the fitsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡f_{i}^{t}. Based on Lemma 1, the upper bound of Dtsubscript𝐷𝑡D_{t} can be similarly obtained using spectral graph theory as if the federated function 𝒇tsubscript𝒇𝑡\bm{f}_{t} were a numerical vector.

Theorem 1

If the network graph is connected, the sharing rate satisfies 0<ε≤12​Δ0𝜀12Δ0<\varepsilon\leq\frac{1}{2\Delta}, and Assumptions 1 and 2 hold, Dtsubscript𝐷𝑡D_{t} is upper bounded as follows:

Dt≤1n​∥𝒇1∥Φn​κ2t−1+Km​∑τ=1t−1ητ​κ2t−τ,subscript𝐷𝑡1𝑛subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒇1subscriptΦ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜅2𝑡1subscript𝐾msuperscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1subscript𝜂𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜅2𝑡𝜏\displaystyle D_{t}\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\lVert\bm{f}_{1}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}\kappa_{2}^{t-1}+K_{\mathrm{m}}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\eta_{\tau}\kappa_{2}^{t-\tau}, (22)

where we define κ2≔1−ε​λ2≔subscript𝜅21𝜀subscript𝜆2\kappa_{2}\coloneqq 1-\varepsilon\lambda_{2} and Km≔maxi⁡{Si​Ki}≔subscript𝐾msubscript𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖K_{\mathrm{m}}\coloneqq\max_{i}\left\{\sqrt{S_{i}}K_{i}\right\}.

Proof:

See Appendix C. ∎

Because λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} does not exceed twice the maximum degree ΔΔ\Delta of the network graph, if the sharing rate ε𝜀\varepsilon is selected to satisfy 0<ε≤12​Δ0𝜀12Δ0<\varepsilon\leq\frac{1}{2\Delta}, we have 0≤κ2<10subscript𝜅210\leq\kappa_{2}<1. Because we assume that the learning rate ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} monotonically decreases, the right-hand side (RHS) of (22) is bounded as follows:

γtsubscript𝛾𝑡\displaystyle\gamma_{t} ≔1n​∥𝒇1∥Φn​κ2t−1+Km​∑τ=1t−1ητ​κ2t−τ≔absent1𝑛subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒇1subscriptΦ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜅2𝑡1subscript𝐾msuperscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1subscript𝜂𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜅2𝑡𝜏\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\lVert\bm{f}_{1}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}\kappa_{2}^{t-1}+K_{\mathrm{m}}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\eta_{\tau}\kappa_{2}^{t-\tau}
≤1n​∥𝒇1∥Φn​κ2t−1+Km​η1​κ2​(1−κ2t−1)1−κ2.absent1𝑛subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒇1subscriptΦ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜅2𝑡1subscript𝐾msubscript𝜂1subscript𝜅21superscriptsubscript𝜅2𝑡11subscript𝜅2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left\lVert\bm{f}_{1}\right\rVert_{\Phi_{n}}\kappa_{2}^{t-1}+K_{\mathrm{m}}\eta_{1}\frac{\kappa_{2}(1-\kappa_{2}^{t-1})}{1-\kappa_{2}}. (23)

The limit of Dtsubscript𝐷𝑡D_{t} is bounded by the constant value as follows:

limt→∞Dt≤η1​κ2​Km1−κ2=η1​(1−ε​λ2)​Kmε​λ2.subscript→𝑡subscript𝐷𝑡subscript𝜂1subscript𝜅2subscript𝐾m1subscript𝜅2subscript𝜂11𝜀subscript𝜆2subscript𝐾m𝜀subscript𝜆2\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}D_{t}\leq\frac{\eta_{1}\kappa_{2}K_{\mathrm{m}}}{1-\kappa_{2}}=\frac{\eta_{1}(1-\varepsilon\lambda_{2})K_{\mathrm{m}}}{\varepsilon\lambda_{2}}. (24)

Next, we discuss the optimality of f¯tsubscript¯𝑓𝑡\bar{f}_{t}. Because the subgradient method is not a descent method, we consider the best solution yet found in a similar manner as discussed in [35]. The best solution fbest,tsubscript𝑓best𝑡f_{\mathrm{best},t} is defined as fbest,t≔arg​minτ=1,…,t⁡{𝖫μ​(f¯τ)}≔subscript𝑓best𝑡subscriptargmin𝜏1…𝑡subscript𝖫𝜇subscript¯𝑓𝜏f_{\mathrm{best},t}\coloneqq\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\tau=1,\dots,t}\left\{\mathsf{L}_{\mu}\left(\bar{f}_{\tau}\right)\right\}.

Although it is not guaranteed that the sub-gradient method strictly decreases 𝖫μ​(f¯t)subscript𝖫𝜇subscript¯𝑓𝑡\mathsf{L}_{\mu}(\bar{f}_{t}), a decreasing series can be obtained by tuning the learning rate.

IV-C CMFD as an implementation for neural networks

Because the meta-algorithm works in a function space, practical implementation is required. We developed a CMFD for NNs by extending FL. The meta-algorithm directly updates functions using (13) and (14). CMFD substitutes these two operations by updating the parameters of the NN models, that is, SGD and distillation. The pseudocode of the proposed algorithm is presented in Algorithm 2.

First, we simply substitute the Fréchet subgradient in (13) with a stochastic gradient in a parameter space (steps 4–6). Device i𝑖i updates its local prediction models f​(⋅;𝒘i)𝑓⋅subscript𝒘𝑖f(\cdot;\bm{w}_{i}) using the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. Note that the gradient calculated at each local device in step 5 is expected to be an approximation of dit​νisuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡subscript𝜈𝑖d_{i}^{t}\nu_{i} rather than ditsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑡d_{i}^{t} in (13), because 𝒟^^𝒟\hat{\mathcal{D}} is a mini-batch of 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, which is also exposed to the distribution skew.

CMFD utilizes distillation, where devices share the input and output pairs of their prediction models instead of the parameters to aggregate the prediction models. This is because parameter averaging (12) cannot realize function aggregation (14) due to the non-convexity of local functions.

Fig. 2 shows the concept of distillation-based function aggregation. Points in Fig. 2 represent the positions of the functions in a function space. The red, blue, and green points represent the local prediction function before the aggregation step, the mean of the prediction functions of the adjacent devices, and the weighted mean of these two functions, respectively. Regarding the blue points as a distillation target, the local prediction function approaches the green points by a gradient descent scheme. Here, the loss function for distillation c​(𝒘^it+1)𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1c({\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t+1}) is defined as follows:

c​(𝒘^it+1)𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle c({\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t+1}) ≔∑(𝒙,𝒚)∈𝒟s∥f​(𝒙;𝒘^it+1)−1ni​∑j∈𝒩i𝒚^j,𝒙t+1∥2.≔absentsubscript𝒙𝒚subscript𝒟ssuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝒙superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡11subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝒚𝑗𝒙𝑡12\displaystyle\coloneqq\sum_{(\bm{x},\bm{y})\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}}}\Big{\lVert}f(\bm{x};{\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t+1})-\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}{\hat{\bm{y}}_{j,\bm{x}}}^{t+1}\Big{\rVert}^{2}. (27)

MSE is used as a loss function because it is an empirical representation of the Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} distance between two functions. Fortunately, c​(𝒘^it+1)𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1c({\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t+1}) can be calculated without the information of the adjacent devices’ models but only with their outputs, and thus, only the outputs should be shared among the devices.

The devices calculate outputs 𝒚^i,xt+1superscriptsubscript^𝒚𝑖𝑥𝑡1{\hat{\bm{y}}_{i,x}}^{t+1} of public dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}}, and send them to their neighbors 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i} (steps 7–10). By using the received values, the devices update their models by distillation assuming the aggregate outputs 1ni​∑j∈𝒩i𝒚^j,𝒙t+11subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝒚𝑗𝒙𝑡1\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}{\hat{\bm{y}}_{j,\bm{x}}}^{t+1} as new labels as follows (step 15):

𝒘it+1superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{w}_{i}^{t+1} ←𝒘^it+1−ε​ni​∇𝒘c​(𝒘^it+1).←absentsuperscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1𝜀subscript𝑛𝑖subscript∇𝒘𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\leftarrow{\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t+1}-\varepsilon n_{i}\nabla_{\bm{w}}c({\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t+1}). (28)

Note that complete distillation at each iteration is not required, because distillation steps are derived from (14), the RHS of which is defined as the weighted mean of the local model git+1superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑡1g_{i}^{t+1} and (1/n)​∑j∈𝒩igjt+11𝑛subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑗𝑡1(1/n)\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}g_{j}^{t+1}. Therefore, a small update by distillation is sufficient for approximating (14), and we performed one epoch for distillation at each iteration in the evaluations in Sec. V. After sufficient iterations of the SGD with local datasets and distillation with public datasets, all the local models are expected to approach the optimal solution of (10), even though the parameters 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i} are not forced to be the same values by Algorithm 2.

We use an additional public dataset, 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}}, as the input data for distillation. Dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} is selected randomly from open data by specifying the category of the input domain, e.g., animal images for animal recognition tasks and human images for activity recognition tasks. Although the local datasets 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} are non-IID because of users’ interests, the public dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} is expected to be the empirical representation of the global measure μ𝜇\mu. The selected dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} is shared among the devices before the learning algorithm is initiated. Note that the labels of 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} are not required, and thus, they are easy to collect. If the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} was used instead of 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} in the distillation steps, MSE would be an approximation of Lμi2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2subscript𝜇𝑖L^{2}_{\mu_{i}} rather than Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu}, and the models would converge to the local optimum in Lμi2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2subscript𝜇𝑖L^{2}_{\mu_{i}}. In addition, local datasets cannot be shared because they may include private information. Therefore, the public dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} is required to aggregate local models in Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} by MSE, and aggregation in Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} realizes the convergence of the models to the optimum in Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu}.

As mentioned above, CMFD is an approximation of the meta-algorithm. This fact provides us with an intuitive understanding of the convergence property of the CMFD, although the convergence is not mathematically guaranteed. First, the local models as functions approach each other regardless of the values of their parameters. Second, the convergence of CMFD improves if (13) and (14) are well approximated. For instance, using a large public dataset should improve performance because the probability measure of 𝒟ssubscript𝒟s\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} approaches μ𝜇\mu, and the distillation becomes a good approximation of (14). Third, several characteristics replicate those of CDO, such that a strong connection improves convergence. We also evaluate the convergence property of CMFD by simulation in the following section and confirm that CMFD can be applied to various ML tasks.

V Performance evaluation

We evaluated CMFD using the public datasets, MNIST [38], fashion MNIST (F-MNIST) [39], CIFAR10, and CIFAR100 [40]. The simulation parameters are presented in Table II. Ten devices were assumed to be connected via multi-hop networks, as shown in Fig. 3. We evaluated the R1, R2, and R3 ring lattice networks and BA1 and BA3 scale-free networks that are occasionally used in WSNs for energy efficiency [41]. The evaluated scale-free networks were generated using the Barabási–Albert (BA) algorithm [42]. In our simulations, the devices had two types of labels to evaluate the non-IID situations. When evaluating ring networks, device #​i#𝑖\#i possessed training data labeled i𝑖i and ((i+1)mod10)modulo𝑖110((i+1)\bmod 10) for 10-class classification tasks and 10​i10𝑖10i through ((10​i+19)mod100)modulo10𝑖19100((10i+19)\bmod 100) for CIFAR100 assuming a situation where nearby devices had similar data distributions, where modmodulo\bmod denotes the modulo operator. Conversely, when evaluating scale-free networks, two types of labels were chosen randomly. One thousand public data samples without ground truth labels were used for the distillation. The local and public datasets were allowed to duplicate. The NN layer architecture was CNN(32,532532,5)-CNN(64,564564,5)-FC(512512512)-FC(101010)111CNN(f,k𝑓𝑘f,k) and FC(n𝑛n) represent the convolution layer with f𝑓f-filters with a kernel size of k×k𝑘𝑘k\times k and the fully connected layer with n𝑛n-hidden nodes.. ReLU was used as the activation function.

We evaluated the performance of the CDO in a parameter space as a parameter-averaging algorithm in multi-hop networks. With this algorithm, each device updates its local models by SGD similar to CMFD (steps 4–6 in Algorithm 2) and send 𝒘^itsuperscriptsubscript^𝒘𝑖𝑡{\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}^{t} to the adjacent devices. Then, the device updates its parameters using (11) and (12). When evaluating the parameter-averaging method, the initial parameters are set to be equal to avoid performance deterioration [1].

V-A Convergence performance

Fig. 4 shows the convergence performance evaluated for accuracy using MNIST, F-MNIST, CIFAR10, and CIFAR100. The figures on the even columns show the performance of the parameter-averaging method as a baseline. Each line in the figures indicates the accuracy of each device. We manually tuned the sharing rate ε𝜀\varepsilon for learning rates η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 and 0.10.10.1. CMFD shows higher accuracy compared with the parameter-averaging method when the network is weakly connected. Moreover, when learning CIFAR100, CMFD outperforms the parameter-averaging method when the network is strongly connected. These results suggest that CMFD has the potential to learn complex datasets compared to the parameter-averaging method. Regardless of which dataset was used, comparing R1 and R3 confirms that accuracy increased more rapidly when the network was strongly connected. Unsurprisingly, the trained models of the ten devices got close faster when the network became dense. Therefore, each device increased the prediction accuracy of unknown labels that the device lacked. It also shows that the fluctuation range of the CMFD is narrower than that of the parameter-averaging algorithm.

Table III lists the average accuracy and the other two metrics at 1000 epochs (F-MNIST) and 2000 epochs (CIFAR10 and CIFAR100) with various parameters. Metric max-min shows the difference in the accuracy of the best and the worse devices, which is a metric of convergence among devices. Label dev shows the averaged standard deviation of each device’s accuracy during the last 100 epochs. Values of max-min confirm that when the learning rate and the sharing rate were well-tuned, the accuracies of the ten devices converged in narrower ranges with CMFD than parameter averaging. By comparing the deviations of the two methods, the fluctuation range of CMFD is approximately one-tenth that of parameter averaging. The difference in stability occurs because the parameter-averaging algorithm attempts to solve a non-convex optimization problem, whereas CMFD is designed to solve a convex optimization problem in a function space. Because there are multiple local optima in a parameter space, when the parameters of devices tend toward different optima, the parameter-updating directions calculated by parameter sharing and gradient descent can differ completely. Conversely, the local prediction functions of devices draw close in a function space by CMFD, which allows different parameters if they are located at the same point in a function space. This difference in stability is significant, especially if the devices are weakly connected, because the variance of the parameter-updating directions increases owing to the small number of adjacent devices when using the parameter-averaging scheme. In contrast, CMFD, which aims to aggregate functions directly, is not exposed to a major variance in the function-updating directions even with few adjacent devices.

Table III lists the evaluated results of PDMM [6] as the state-of-the-art decentralized FL. The communication frequency of PDMM is set such that the number of transmissions is approximately same as CMFD and parameter averaging because PDMM is an asynchronous algorithm, whereas CMFD is a synchronous algorithm. In this setting, the amount of transmitted data is twice as large as that of parameter averaging. Although PDMM achieves high convergence among devices and high accuracy even when devices are weakly connected, CMFD outperforms PDMM in terms of accuracy on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. CMFD regards learning tasks as convex function optimization problems, whereas PDMM and parameter averaging attempt to solve non-convex optimization problems in the parameter space. Therefore, CMFD achieves higher accuracy for difficult tasks compared with the other methods.

V-B Heterogeneous environment

Fig. 5 shows accuracy as a function of the sharing rates using different types of NN models. Model A’s layer architecture was CNN(32,532532,5)-CNN(64,564564,5)-FC(512512512)-FC(101010), which is identical to that used in the previous evaluation. Model B was evaluated as a shallow NN with CNN(8,5858,5)-FC(323232)-FC(101010)-layer architecture. The green and blue lines show the accuracy when all devices adopted models A and B, respectively. The red line shows the accuracy when half of the ten devices adopted model A and the others adopted model B considering a situation where the devices had different computational resources. During the evaluation, the devices with an even-numbered index had rich resources and adopted model A, and the others had poor resources and adopted shallow model B. CMFD works even when devices adopt different NN models, whereas FL algorithms using parameter averaging require the devices to adopt the same NN model. Because model B is shallow, its accuracy is lower than that of model A when the network topology is R1. In contrast, when the connectivity increased, the accuracy of model B increased to the same level as that of model A. This implies that the restrictions of local training perturbed the learning process, and the shallow model could not fulfill its potential. When the two types of models were adopted by the different devices, those that adopted model B achieved nearly the same performance as those using model A. Such characteristics enable IoE devices with different computational resources to cooperatively learn the same task.

We conducted another simulation using three types of models—model A, MobileNetV3 Small [43], and ResNet18 [44]—to verify whether CMFD can learn more complex models in heterogeneous settings. Fig. 6 shows the accuracy as a function of the number of epochs when five or ten devices learn F-MNIST. Each line represents the average accuracy among all devices. When the number of devices is five, each device possesses a dataset consisting of four categories, and the number of local data samples is 2000. The dropout rate was set to 0.1, and the other parameters are listed in Table II. The input images were resized to 96×96969696\times 96 before being input into MobileNetV3 and ResNet18 because these models are considerably deep, and the image sizes decrease to one pixel in the last layer without expansion. We substituted layer normalization [45] for batch normalization [46] in MobileNetV3 and ResNet18 because batch normalization is not suitable for non-IID datasets [6]. Fig. 6 shows that CMFD can train models with non-IID datasets in heterogeneous scenarios even though the numbers of the layers of the models are widely different: Model A has only four layers, while MobileNetV3 Small and ResNet18 have 16 and 18 layers, respectively.

V-C Comparison with various sharing rates

Various topologies are compared in Fig. 7, which shows the average accuracy as a function of the sharing rate. The accuracy indicated by the label “BA (dynamic)” shows the performance when the network topology dynamically changed at each epoch to evaluate situations where the mobile devices were in motion. This shows that even if the topology changes dynamically, the accuracy converges to the same value. Notably, these results also support that CMFD is highly stable even when it is applied via wireless networks with considerable noise because a dynamic topology emulates a situation with unstable links. When comparing the topologies, the accuracy of R3 was slightly better than that of R2, BA2, and dynamic BA. However, the accuracy of R1 and BA1 was poorer than that of the others. These differences arise from the algebraic connectivity λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} in (24) and (26). Table IV lists the algebraic connectivities and average degrees of the evaluated topologies. Because the connectivity of R2, BA2, and dynamic BA are similar, they achieved similar performance. Similarly, the accuracy of R1 and BA1 were similar because they had similar connectivity.

When evaluating ring topologies, adjacent devices have the same labels when evaluating ring networks, whereas randomly selected labels are distributed when evaluating BA networks. Despite such data-distribution differences, they achieved similar accuracy if the connectivity of the topologies was nearly identical. Therefore, it can be said that the data distribution similarity among adjacent devices does not affect accuracy.

V-D Scalability to the number of devices

Fig. 8 shows the average accuracy and distillation losses for various numbers of devices. The distillation loss is MSE c​(𝒘^i)𝑐subscript^𝒘𝑖c({\hat{\bm{w}}_{i}}), defined in (27). This metric indicates the similarity of NN models among adjacent devices because MSE is an empirical representation of the Lμ2subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝜇L^{2}_{\mu} distance. It is shown that distillation losses decrease with the number of epochs, which means that the local models approach each other in the function space, even though the parameters of the local models are not forced to converge by CMFD. Topologies varied at each epoch using the BA algorithm, but the number of all edges remained stable. The connectivity for different numbers of devices are listed in Table V. The listed algebraic connectivity reflects the averages of 100 randomly generated graphs. When evaluating MNIST, the learning and sharing rates were set to 0.01 and 0.1, respectively. Both rates were set to 0.1 when evaluating F-MNIST. Fig. 8 shows that even when the number of devices increases, the NN models converge at nearly the same rate. This is because, as shown in Table V, the averages of algebraic connectivity are approximately the same regardless of the number of devices. These results indicate that the proposed algorithm works with a large number of devices as long as the connectivity does not change drastically.

V-E Amount of transferred data

One of the advantages of using distillation is that the amount of shared data is smaller than that of parameter averaging schemes. When using CMFD, the amount of data transferred via each link per epoch is 40 KB for |𝒟s|=1000subscript𝒟s1000|{\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}}}|=1000 and 400 KB for |𝒟s|=10000subscript𝒟s10000|{\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}}}|=10000. Here, all values are encoded in a four-byte-floating-point format. When using the parameter averaging scheme, the amount of transferred data is 6.7 MB with model A, and 202 KB for model B, respectively. Because distillation-based methods require only to share the output values, when the input values are shared in advance, the data volume can be smaller than the parameter-averaging schemes when NN models have many parameters.

VI Conclusion

We propose a model-free federated learning scheme for IoE devices connected via multi-hop networks. We developed a meta-algorithm for consensus-based optimization in a function space that optimizes the loss function in a distributed manner. The convergence of the meta-algorithm in a function space was mathematically analyzed using federated functions. Federated functions represent the joint status of the entire system, enabling us to obtain an upper bound of the distance between the local prediction functions. Then, we propose a CMFD as an implementation of the meta-algorithm, which realizes function aggregation among adjacent devices by leveraging a distillation method. We showed that the CMFD achieved higher prediction accuracy and stability than a typical parameter-aggregation-based FL when a multi-hop network is weakly connected.

Our future work includes improving the algorithm by estimating the reliability of the local prediction functions. When the training data is non-IID, there is a training bias among the devices depending on the data distributions. Although CMFD does not consider the reliability of the prediction accuracy for each label, the learning speed is expected to increase if weighted averaging is adopted when aggregating functions. To calculate the optimal weight, we will develop a method of estimating how well the local prediction function is trained.

Extending CMFD to non-convex optimization is an interesting study. Although usual loss functionals are convex, non-convex functionals exist. We believe that analyses of non-convex optimizations [47, 48] can be extended to function spaces by leveraging Lemma 1, which enables us to utilize the spectral graph theory in function spaces.

Another direction of future work is to apply a decentralized ADMM to CMFD because it can achieve faster convergence compared with gradient-descent-based algorithms. We believe ADMM in a function space can be analyzed similarly to the analysis in Sec. IV. However, some challenges exist. For example, devices have to calculate Fréchet gradients of complex functionals depending on the local prediction functions of adjacent devices to realize ADMM in a function space. This calculation is computationally expensive, and devices must prepare multiple frameworks of NN architectures in advance, which decreases the flexibility of model selection in heterogeneous scenarios. A novel approach should be developed to calculate gradients of NN parameters that correspond to the Fréchet gradients to improve practicality.

Appendix A Toy model of CMFD

Fig. 9 shows a simple example explaining why a distillation-based algorithm is better than those trying to converge parameters. Assume the ground truth model is defined by f⋆​(x)=xsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑥𝑥f^{\star}(x)=x, and two devices #​0#0\#0 and #​1#1\#1 try to estimate f⋆​(x)superscript𝑓⋆𝑥f^{\star}(x) using a three-layer perceptron with one hidden node and an identity activation function. Then, the prediction model fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} of device i𝑖i is represented by fi​(x)=wai​wbi​xsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x)=w_{a}^{i}w_{b}^{i}x. Let denote shared data by xn∈𝒟ssubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝒟sx_{n}\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}} and j≔1−i≔𝑗1𝑖j\coloneqq 1-i.

In the setting, there are two optimal regions in a parameter space, but these regions correspond to the same single point f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star} in a function space. Therefore, this optimization problem is non-convex in the parameter space but convex in the function space.

Consider cases where wai>0,wbi>0,waj<0,wbj<0,wai​wbi<1<waj​wbjformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑖0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑖0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑗0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑗0superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑗w_{a}^{i}>0,w_{b}^{i}>0,w_{a}^{j}<0,w_{b}^{j}<0,w_{a}^{i}w_{b}^{i}<1<w_{a}^{j}w_{b}^{j} as illustrated in Fig. 9. In such cases, when using an algorithm that forces parameter convergence, 𝒘isuperscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}^{i} heads to approach 𝒘jsuperscript𝒘𝑗\bm{w}^{j} and goes away from the optimal region in the first quadrant.

In contrast, the parameters 𝒘isuperscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}^{i} approach the optimal region in the first quadrant with our algorithm because the direction of updates by distillation is calculated as follows:

−∂∂𝒘i​∑x∈𝒟s‖fi​(x)−fj​(x)‖2superscript𝒘𝑖subscript𝑥subscript𝒟ssuperscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥2\displaystyle-\frac{\partial}{\partial\bm{w}^{i}}\sum_{x\in\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{s}}}\|f_{i}(x)-f_{j}(x)\|^{2}
∝−(wai​wbi−waj​wbj)​(wbiwai).proportional-toabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑗matrixsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎𝑖\displaystyle\qquad\propto-(w_{a}^{i}w_{b}^{i}-w_{a}^{j}w_{b}^{j})\begin{pmatrix}w_{b}^{i}\\ w_{a}^{i}\\ \end{pmatrix}.

It is also notable that when 𝒘isuperscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}^{i} and 𝒘jsuperscript𝒘𝑗\bm{w}^{j} reach the different optimal regions, our algorithm successfully stops, while algorithms in parameter space continue to update parameters even though prediction models are identical with f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star}. Therefore, our algorithm achieves better convergence than those converge parameters.
